scripture_body:
1 Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, left the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, 2 where for forty days he was tempted by the devil. He ate nothing during those days, and at the end of them he was hungry.

3 The devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread.”

4 Jesus answered, “It is written: ‘Man shall not live on bread alone.’

5 The devil led him up to a high place and showed him in an instant all the kingdoms of the world. 6 And he said to him, “I will give you all their authority and splendor; it has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to. 7 If you worship me, it will all be yours.”

8 Jesus answered, “It is written: ‘Worship the Lord your God and serve him only.’ ”

9 The devil led him to Jerusalem and had him stand on the highest point of the temple. “If you are the Son of God,” he said, “throw yourself down from here. 10 For it is written:“‘He will command his angels concerning you to guard you carefully; 11 they will lift you up in their hands, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.’ ”

12 Jesus answered, “It is said: ‘Do not put the Lord your God to the test.’ ” 13 When the devil had finished all this tempting, he left him until an opportune time.
goal: To see how Jesus’ reliance on Scripture to ward off temptation underscores the invaluable discipline for us of really knowing God’s word.
background: This week we begin with a new series, “Knowing Jesus,” that will cover the six weeks of Lent. In Epiphany we come to see who Jesus is through his actions and his teaching. Lent is a time to learn about who Jesus is for us—what he came to do for us and our neighbors, and how we all benefit by believing, knowing, and uniting with him. Lent is also a season of preparation for Easter. While all of our life should be characterized by repentance and renewal, Lent enables us to give focused attention to cultivating our spiritual lives. Our growth is by God’s grace, but we play an active role as we “continue to work out our salvation,” knowing that as we do so it is the Lord who is at work in us (Philippians 2:12-13). Each sermon in this series will come from Luke and highlights a spiritual practice the Lord uses to shape us more into the people he has redeemed us to be.

addlSections.body:
Goal for this section: To recognize that times of temptation—and opportunities for growth—tend to come when God has led us into a season of spiritual dryness, a place that’s a wilderness.

1. Review the experience Jesus is having (vv. 1-2) by first recalling what occurred just before this (Luke 3:21-22). What strikes you about Jesus’ desert experience? How does it point to Jesus’ humanity?

** 2. The Test (v. 2): Commentators agree that this passage has clear parallels with Israel’s wanderings in the wilderness. What are some of those parallels and why is this insight important for understanding the meaning of Christ’s temptations?

Goal for this section: To examine how the devil tempted Jesus and see what this reveals about the insidiousness of the schemes the devil uses to cause us to fail.

3. The Temptations (vv. 3-12): In this section we get an inside look at the devil’s methods of temptation. What kinds of needs and desires does he distort in order to tempt Jesus to sin? What implications does this suggest for us? .

Goal for this section: To examine the implications of Jesus’ response to Satan and consider how we might rely on the power of scripture in these situations to resist giving in.

4. The Resistance: What Scriptures did Jesus quote and why? What does his choice of Scripture reveal?

5. Practical Application: Every Christian will find themselves tested in the places that matter most to them, and often during times that are desert-like. How can we apply Jesus’ response in this situation to our own lives? What are some practical ways we can go about meditating on Scripture daily and committing verses to memory so we can use them to resist temptation?

GOAL OF THIS APPLICATION:To reflect on the command in Scripture for us to practice intentional hospitality and examine what holds us back from living that out.

One of the most ancient spiritual practices of the church has been the practice of intentional hospitality towards those who differ from us. It would not be much of an exaggeration to say that this humble hospitality transformed an entire society—and was one of the most powerful ways that ordinary members of the early church went public with their faith and embraced those who didn’t believe. As our sermon series leads us to consider various spiritual practices during this Lenten season, in light of our Public Faith year, we will zero in on this particular practice. This week we begin by examining what Jesus says about hospitality. In the following weeks, we’ll be challenging ourselves us to apply the practice of intentional hospitality to our hearts and lives.

Read the text below as a group and then meditate on the passage on your own for five minutes.

MATTHEW 25:34-40

34 “Then the King will say to those on his right, ‘Come, you who are blessed by my Father; take your inheritance, the kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the world. 35 For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat, I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink, I was a stranger and you invited me in, 36 I needed clothes and you clothed me, I was sick and you looked after me, I was in prison and you came to visit me.’

37 “Then the righteous will answer him, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink? 38 When did we see you a stranger and invite you in, or needing clothes and clothe you? 39 When did we see you sick or in prison and go to visit you?’

40 “The King will reply, ‘Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me.’

After five minutes, discuss the following questions:

6. What are the costs associated with hospitality as it is described in this passage? What might these costs look like for us in New York City today?

7. Thinking differently, what are the costs to us for NOT serving and practicing hospitality?

Christine Pohl in Making Room, her book on hospitality as a spiritual practice says, “The manner in which we welcome people, the interest we show in them, and the time we take for them communicates to them that they are valued.” She goes on to say, “The response we give to an unexpected guest is connected to how that person experiences God’s love and welcome.”

** 8. We all may want to demonstrate God’s love and welcome as she describes it, but what holds us back from extending hospitality to those with different belief systems or worldviews?

9. How can God shape you through friendships with those who don’t identify as a Christian?
